Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
I was looking for wireless headphones for my work and seriously considered Sony 1000X vs. Bose QC 35. While I was watching so many reviews, I found Sony just updated the 1000X, so I jumped into WH 1000XM2! I tried on both 1000XM2 and Bose QC 35 and honestly think that both are great headphones. Sony 1000XM2 has more features and longer battery life so I am very content with my purchase.

#Features
The touchpad is not a new feature but it is worth mentioning since Bose does not have this feature. Swipe up or down to control the volume. Swipe right or left to change the music. It is very intuitive and easy. You can even press long to activate Siri. Double tap to stop music or take a phone call.
Also, you can cup the right ear and disable the noise canceling and listen to others.

You can check the battery level by the home screen of a smartphone. I have only seen even numbers such as 100%, 70%, and 50% (then I would charge so I have not seen low numbers because of the reason). Maybe the headphone cannot tell the battery level precisely.

#Bluetooth connection
Bluetooth connection is great. I can leave my phone and go to next room without breaking the connection. Switching the devices is not easy though. With Bose, you can connect two devices at the same time. However, with 1000XM2, you need to disconnect one device to use other device.

To switch the device (updated)
1. Go to setting. Bluetooth, then disconnect WH-1000XM2.
2. Go to the other device, hit setting, Bluetooth, then click to connect.

If you don't want to touch the device connected currently but wans to switch the device (for example, 1000XM2 is connected to iPad that is in your bag and you don't want to pull it out), you can
1. Turn off the 1000XM2
2. Turn on and keep pressing power button to activate bluetooth pairing.
3. Go to your device you want to connect. Hit setting, bluetooth, then connect to 1000XM2.

Honestly, I don't mind doing this but I wish we could connect two iOS devices at the same time.

#Noise canceling
Sony and Bose are both excellent noise cancelling (NC) headphones. While QC35 cannot turn off the NC, 1000XM2 can turn of NC. Previous 1000X had a problem with phone call where you cannot hear yourself (so you end up shouting). Sony has fixed this problem and now 1000XM2 let you hear your voice easily with voice focus mode. Making phone call is much easier now.

#Sony headphone connect app
This app allows you to change the setting of NC based on your activity. You can pre-set the level of NC + voice focus according to your activity (rest, walking, running, and transportation). For frequent fliers, it can adjust the pressure too. You can also change where the sound comes from. For example, you can set as if the sound comes from your back.

When I was using 1000XM2 in the office, I used voice focus mode. It was very interesting experience because I did not hear any noise from construction etc but I heard my coworkers voice. Voice is picked up from the mic so it is an interesting experience.

#Gorgeous look
It honestly looks fantastic. I usually pick the black color but I tried gold at this time. The case of headphone had two-tone color (gold in the middle). It looks great. Please look at attached pictures as it tells you more how nice it looks. The headphone has hinges so you can actually make it very small and put it into the case.

#Sound
I cannot speak too much about the sound because I am not a professional musician. However, in my opinion, it sounds absolutely nice. It sounds even better than Bose QC35 but it is just my opinion. With the connect app, you can also change the sound effect such as Arena, Club, Outdoor Stage, and Concert Hall. It is subjective so you might want to try it before you buy, but I am very much satisfied.

#Comfort
This is where BOSE QC35 (quiet comfort) comes into play. WH 1000XM2 is comfortable but I feel my ears are hot after using this for 1 hour. The pad is touching my ears with 1000XM2 whereas QC35 has deeper ear pad. QC35 is much more comfortable for me.

#Sturdy design
I know cracking was the problem with 1000X. So far, it has been OK but I will definitely give updates after using several months (hope nothing will happen). It looks very sturdy and does not make the clicking sound when I open the headphone.

So which one you should buy? I am very happy with 1000XM2 because it has many features and long battery life (30 hours!). However, you may want to try it on before you buy because BOSE is more comfortable.

Reviews:
These headphones are one of my favourite things. They are so well built and are fully sound cancelling. I had the MDR1000x before this and decided to upgrade for the better battery life and app support. I’m going to list the pros and cons I’ve encountered so far and give some recommendations. FYI, I’ve never owned (but have tested) the QC35, beats solo and studio, and own the Senhiessers 550HD.

-Pros-
1) These are top notch in terms of noise cancelation and isolation. The mdr1000x were great and these are the same if not a step up. I could be mowing or trimming the lawn and if I close my eyes I’m in a totally different world. Can’t tell a machine is functioning in front of me.
2) Touchpad: this is such a cool feature. I’m an adoptee of new tech and have been loving it. Sometimes it doesn’t register my hand gestures but I mean it’s not the end of the world. Always registers the second time. The palm over to bring outside noise is super cool, but no one on the other end knows what’s going on. I’d be on a bus and talk to the driver and he’d think I’m on the phone and ignore me. But super cool nonetheless!
3) Battery life, 30-40 hours is Sony’s estimate I believe I’ve been getting very close to that as I go on walks and listen to music while studying overall super happy about it!
4) App is easy to use to pick between different general modes. Kinda cool. One con about this is I use tidal and the music centre only functions with Apple Music (I just use iOS and tidal. Dunno about Spotify or other platforms.
5) These headphones work great wirelessly and last long. But a great pro to them is when you connect the wires you get even better quality! Who knew that could be possible. Another pro is you could use the headphones when dead (without any of the extra bells and whistles) so having the wire on you is the equivalent to carrying another pair of headphones ;)

-Cons-
1) Potential chance of crack? I had the MDR 1000x for months and did not face the crack issues other have. But in my opinion, I totally agree with the video listed where the guy says the cracks are an easy con for the many pros and it’s something you should consider for yourself whether you care enough about that. Are there better speakers out there for the same price range? Yes. Do they have the same functions the Sony has? Not likely (touchpad particularly) is it worth its money? Yes!
2) The bag is the exact same and not very well made in my opinion. Nice that Sony puts it I but I mean you’ll likely want to get one yourself.
3) Connectivity not as (I’ve heard) easy as QC35 or others. Honestly, this isn’t a huge con but I listed it so you can have it in perspective. Do you want to connect to another device? Disconnect from the Bluetooth settings and connect to them on the other device. If the device is in your bag hold the power button to turn off, then continue to hold it after it turns on until it says pairing. I use 5 devices and this hasn’t been an issue for me.

This pair of headphones is well packaged and, in my humble opinion, well priced. You risk it having a small crack, I’ve never had, but for all the extras you get, it’s well worth it. Another thing is Sony did price it lower than the older model so it’s not like they’re charging extra for more functions. The pad sometimes doesn’t register stuff, but I think that’s more me getting used to it than it getting used to me. It's a give and take situation it does stuff for you but you have to learn to function with it and around its flaws.

A few things to improve on would be to have the headphones announce what they’re connected to rather than just staying connected. I believe this won’t be hard for Sony to add through the app, could be wrong, and then again it might not be something they want to do, to begin with. Would’ve loved to see USB type-C on this model. USB-C is the future would be great when small gadgets like this embrace that.

I’d recommend these to anyone who is looking to get a good quality headphone that is versatile with great sound cancelling and new technology. This is and will be for some time my daily driver for headphones.

Hope this helps some of you decide whether it’s a good fit for you — I’ll update this as time goes in regards to my experience with battery life, the infamous cracks and such.

I'll keep it short. I read the reviews of the Sony WH1000XM2 and the Bose QuietComfort 35 II and could not decide which to choose, so I bought both. I will return the Sony and keep the Bose. Here are the pros and cons:

Sony:
+ Crisper highs and deeper bass (I can't see how anyone says the Bose model sounds better)
+ Better song navigation with the figure gestures on side of right headpiece
- When making phone calls, those on the other end hear more of your background noise than on the Bose (I tested by calling from a land line to a family member who used my Sonys)
- Heavy on the head and hurts to wear for long periods (this was a deal breaker for me)
- Finger navigation feature is too sensitive sometimes - easy to skip/rewind songs by accident.

Bose
+ Great noise cancellation, especially with no music (better than Sony's)
+ Light weight and definitely more comfortable for long periods
+ Best for phone calls (those on other end don't hear much background noise)
- Sound is missing crispness at high and low ends; overall sounds are a bit muffled (it would be great to get Sony's sound on these speakers). If music quality is your deal breaker, buy the Sonys for sure.

In the end, I couldn't get over the uncomfortable aspect of the Sonys. I really preferred the Sony sound, but didn't see myself wearing the Sonys for long periods of time. My primary reason for buying these was muffling office and plane engine noise for long periods of time, therefore comfort was a deal breaker. It also helps that I can take conference calls on these.

Reviews: I bought these headphones to replace my top-of-the-line Sony MDR-1RNC headphones, which have unbelievably great sound quality but they have been acting up lately (very frustrating). Let me first say that out of the box, the new 1000XM2 headphones had a little better noise cancelling than the MDR-1RNCs but the sound quality was not even close to what I was hoping for. The sound of these new headphones was really muddy with way to much mid-bass frequencies. But then I discovered the iPhone/iPad App for the WH1000XM2s which allows you to customize equalization settings (among other things). After reducing the level at 400 Hz (the muddy frequency range), increasing the levels for 1K, 2.5K, 6.3K, and 16K, and then increasing the level for clear bass (the lowest bass setting), I was able to get the nice V-shaped frequency response that make these headphones sound fantastic. No more mud, everything is crystal clear but not harsh, and the bass is really punchy without drowning out the mids and highs. It sounds great for all genres that I’ve tested (jazz, orchestral, pop, soundtrack, etc). I’ve attached an image of my equalization settings for anybody who wants to give what I did a try. Also, the Bluetooth connection works/sounds great with my iPad and iPhone and the battery seems to last a long time before needing to be recharged. So, these are now my go-to headphones for fun listening with unrivaled noise cancelling.

Reviews:
I've been using these daily for a couple of months now so I could really provide a great review. I use these to block noise in loud data centers while on the phone and for listening to music. These replaced a set of Bose headphones that my wife claimed as her own. Overall I like these more than the Bose set and here's why.
Noise Cancelling - my Bose headset is an older set (it's 7 years old now) but the noise cancelling on these is every bit as good as these are for the noise in a data center. If you've never been in a data center, it's a constant cacophony of high speed fans with more 'background' noise than found in normal commercial aircraft. It's the ultimate test for noise cancelling. I put these on and the noise level was decreased dramatically just from the well padded ear cups. Then I turn it on. Blissful near silence. Sure, I can hear some of the ancillary noises, but for the first time I can hear the subtle beeping of computers doing their thing. Way cool.
Next, I fire up my music app of choice - Pandora. I have an eclectic taste in music - U2 to Beethoven, Collective Soul to Moby, and just about everything in between. Unlike the Bose, the overall sound response is crisp, clear, and balanced. The Bose kit seemed a little bass heavy to me. Music is reproduced without hiss, buzz, or other artifacts.
Excited by this, I head home and fire up my lossless music subscription and bring up a collection of Jazz greats. I can hear it all. Wood creaking as the artist shifts their seat. The soft 'clump' of valves. No hiss. And this is through the bluetooth connection, NOT through the included cable. Amazing.
Now, I'm not a crazy audiophile. I've been plagued with tinnitus since birth so much of the subtle points is lost on me simply because of the ringing BUT I've been able to hear things using this set of headphones from music that I've never heard before WHILE in a loud data center.
I've worn these constantly for 10+ hours and aside from a little warmth, they were extremely comfortable. Battery life is every bit of 20 hours with no need to recharge after two days of heavy use.
The app that you can use with these is pretty easy to use and has some unique features. It is able to detect your actions and adjust noise cancellations accordingly. If you are on the street perhaps you want to me more aware of your surroundings. If you are sitting in a chair perhaps you want to block out more noise. This system will detect and adapt automatically. It's pretty effective and actually detects things pretty well. Going for a walk reduced the cancellation levels while sitting in my office increased it. Using the other tools is likely more of a gimmick - different sound stages (arena, outdoors, etc) Meh - not much difference really. Being able to change the directionality of the sound is also fun to play with and is very effective, but I fail to see the real point of this. Other neat features are the ability to control the headset using 'gestures' - tap to pause, swipe to change volume or advance tracks, and cup to enhance conversation. These are all extremely effective and useful. The 'cupping' motion continues to block lower mhz sound (jet engines, etc) while enhancing the sound range of normal human voices. Short conversations are easy even without taking these off. Swiping quickly becomes second nature and is extremely effective.
Bottom line is this - after owning several of the Bose offerings and really linking them, this set does a better job of faithfully recreating the original intent of sound to your ears than the Bose set does. Bose headsets are WONDERFUL and some of the music I listen to does sound better coming from them (I'm looking at you, dubstep), much of the other music is cleaner coming from these. Noise cancelling is jaw droppingly effective. Battery life is phenomenal. Overall the sound quality and technical features built in to this edge out the Bose in an unofficial head to head comparison.

Whenever I move my head and there is little pressure on my left side of head, there is a squeaky sound and it is annoying. Firstly, this annoying squeaky sound inside the cup still exists. This replacement pair squeaks less than the first one to be honest, however, the problem still remains. If SONY reads this, I have a theory why this happens. I think the speaker cone works like a suction cup or plunger creating the crumbling sound from this flimsy speaker cone material whenever the cup is being pushed toward. Perhaps, few invisible tiny bits of vent holes can prevent this issue. I don't know how it will affect the noise isolation. Please, look into it.

Secondly, when it is connected via its audio cable, it works as advertised. Problem solved. Hooray~.

Lastly, I think this may be a mere software or phone specific (Samsung Galaxy S5) issue. Whenever I change the sound priority option, the headphone turns off and has to be reconnected. I hope this can be fixed by any future update.

I think this is a good pair of cans with great sound, superb noise cancelling and lots of useful functions. Yet, I think its craftsmanship falls a bit short as a premium headphone. Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
First and foremost I hope this review those who have been thinking about these headphones to make a good decision whether these headphones are really for you and not compulsively buy the Sony WH1000XM2. So this review will be pretty detailed concerning these headphones. To get it out of the way, yes, these are the best sounding headphones with the most potential on the average consumer flagship market right now. After reading many reviews, I find that not everyone is a tech enthusiast or know holistically about these. So I will address the problems then get into what I like.

Do these suffer from the same cracking issue as the mdr?: From my experience, they have not. The hinges are mostly a plastic finish with some metallic bands encircling the arch of the headphone and no these are not water resistant. This makes the headphones sturdy, however, with a sufficient enough stress, you can crack the hinges on the headphones. You can also hurt the overall durability but stretching the headphone to far constantly. Jimmy reviews did a stress test but that was mainly the outside arch and not the inside hinges, which are durable so far.

Why do these sound different across phones?: Sony really pushes advertising for LDAC, if you do not own a Sony phone or own an android phone with android oreo (any phone that came out before 2017 barring the google pixel). Do not worry, most 2016 flagships will be getting android oreo later this year which will come LDAC. If you do not own an LDAC compatible device then you will notice a DRASTIC change in sound quality. Not to say that phones without LDAC will not sound good but the older your phone, the less bit rates it can transfer to the headphones which affects the quality. Those who own android 8 (or those that are sony fans in general) are the ones touting how amazing these headphones are. I noticed that those with older phones were the ones complaining how they were not up to par, typically, there are some who talked about how they were great but not on Bose level with android oreo 8 phones and sony phones but it was very few.

Are these bass heavy?: These are bass heavy depending on your sound stage and your EQ settings. The Sony's have Arena, Club, Concert, Outside stage or off (neutral sound). Also depends on whether you have DSEE HX active on auto or not (mainly CD quality or not). By the way, in order to customize the sound you need to have an emphasis on stable connection. An emphasis on sound quality will mean that your headphones will optimize the song for you. You will need to use the Sony app (this is not compatible with the MDR as it is a software limnitation). There are two more aps such as the sony music app that you really do not need and another app called smart connect. Essentially controlling what your headphones do at a certain time. Such as noting that at 4:00 you can call a friend that time. Or playing a certain song at a time (which I assumed is where the music center comes into play)

Club: The most bass heavy soundstage of the four. It sounds as if you are right in front of the stereo that is playing. In short, this works with bass dominant EQ settings with high volumes. It can work with mellow songs but it is more geared towards bass.

Arena: Ever been at a music festival or hardstyle's Qlimax? It sounds like you are in the middle. So the music is farther away and this sound stage places an emphasis on vocals and bass (with a far away reverb effect) so you there are 3 drivers that work to create this. This is primarily good for mid bass emphasis and treble heavy songs. Vocals also go well with this but can go with another sound stage.

Concert: As the name implies, as if you at a music concert. Vocal heavy sounds are recommended moreso than bass heavy songs. There is a lot of reverb with this sound stage so prepare to hear a lot of echo which actually sounds wonderful. Bass heavy songs are hit or miss. Beethoven, thomas bergusen, mark petrie, other choir songs work. Treble is nice here too.

Outside stage. Combine club and arena. Good amount of bass and vocals, This can essentially work with any song, it is kind of like off but the best for average optimization as the music feels more "alive" so to speak. if you have a balance enough amount of bass and treble with a bit more emphasis on vocals in your EQ, then you will get the most out of this sound stage. The song still sounds less in your face as the club sound stage but still great nonetheless.

Off: How you would listen to any headphone really without any additives and just your EQ.

Are these better than the beats studio 3, Bose QC II, Senheiser px550: IT really depends on your taste.each produce their own sound, some people like the bose for the comfort, if you are comfortable while listing to music, your music naturally sounds better. They are definitely better than beats though, but between senheiser, bose, and these pair, you will not really be disappointed. The willikans are also amazing but their comfortably is abysmal in my opinion.

I mainly chose the Sony because it is not a one trick pony and actually offers a variety of options and features that makes these headphones great. What blows you away is really up to how you customize your headphones, how loud the volume is, your EQ, your sound stage. It never distorts which is nice.

You can control the direction of where the sound comes from as well. This is useful if you are in an area where you need to talk to someone but change the a hip-hop song to feel like it is coming from behind you so you can still hear the person talking. On that note, it is important to mention that using this option, automatically shuts off any sound stage you are using and reverts it back to off. Your EQ will be fine though and DSSE HX will be fine.

The best feature is probably how you can change your noise cancellation in 20 levels and whether you want a focus on voice, not only that, you can have it automatically adjust depending on what you are doing. These are not the first to do this, the nuhera earbuds did this but the technology was early and thus it was not really all that good. Dare I say that Sony has perfected it. At 0 you cannot hear anything while music is playing and you only really hear someone if they are shouting at the top of their lungs or if you get hit by a cup by one of your coworkers to get your attention. At 20, you can hear all your surrounding or you can place your hand over the right earcup to block out sound and lowers the volume (if the volume was high, you still hear the song but it is still faint). Best in ANC right now

You can also activate the assistent by long pressing the right earcup then just speak. It is a bit better than cheaper earphones as you need to wait for awhile. Not as good as bose though as that is near instant but nice enough.

The main bad thing is the comfortability, while these are decent to wear, not as comfortable as Bose but after awhile, your ears can feel pressured by the earcup. You have to adjust the earcup to your ears manually (It is kind of odd to explain) but it fits that way. Even then, you can feel uncomfortable after about an 1 or 3 hours if you're used to them.

Overall, these are wonderful headphones for the money right now. If you do not have a phone that has LDAC then these will still sound great but you may feel as if "maybe these can do a bit more". You will not be dsappointed, any additional feature is already in description and features. The atomospheric pressure just makes your song slow down as the altitude gets higher, it solves a problem nobody had but is nice none the less. You will not be disappointed by this pair but still surf around. If you okay with headphones with moderate comfortably but with amazing sound and a variety of features then these will do the job.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
I've used both the Bose QC35I and these, and decided to go with the 1000XM2s. Overall, the package of the Sonys feels more premium than the Bose, as far as finish and the technology. I can't speak on detailed comparison of the ANC, but Sony's definitely sounds at least as good as Bose's, and I think it's really cool how it has adaptive sensing as well as calibration for hairstyle/glasses and air pressure. I have no idea how much of a difference it makes compared to Bose, but just the fact that it's there gives it extra value for me. Additionally, the Sony app includes different sound stage adjustments to make it sound as if you're listening in a concert hall, outdoor stadium, etc, and has automatic and manual EQ adjustments. Bose has none of these features.

The Sony also has distinctly better sound quality than the Bose does. It's cleaner and richer, whereas the Bose has somewhat muddied mid-tones and highs. The touch controls on the Sony took a little bit to get used to, but in the end I think they give you much more control than the Bose, and the ability to place your palm against the control panel to allow ambient sound in through the microphones is a cool touch.

Comfort is where the Sony falls short, but just slightly. The ear muffs on the Sony get warm and a bit clammy after extended use and can cause some uncomfortable pressure on the earlobes, whereas I found the Bose stayed away from my ears due to the angled design of the inside mesh. Still, you can expect to wear the Sony's for hours and be comfortable.

Update: I had my first chance to use these on a 13 hour flight to Asia. I have to say that the noise canceling on these is far more comfortable than on the Bose QCs, which on a train ride created that odd, pressurized feeling in my ears. I'm not sure if my ears had just grown used to the noise canceling inverse waveform, but on my flight I felt no discomfort. It's amazing how more comfortable a long flight can be when you cut out that constant drone of engine noise, listen to music, and get slightly more restful sleep.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
I purchased both this and the Bose QuietComfort 35 Series II to compare the two. I liked that the Sony has an interactive app that shows me how it's calculating the noise cancelling (and it is noticeably improved after the calculation). The app also lets you choose different equalizer settings, including custom settings, which I like because I have hearing loss and I could customize it to my exact hearing needs. The controls are pretty slick, just swiping on the side of the earcup instead of hunting for a button. The sound quality of the music is excellent.

However, here is why I ultimately chose the Bose, and it comes down to two things. Noise cancelling, and advanced sound processing. Re Noise cancellation, I recorded myself in the voice memo app on my phone using the both sets of headphones as the recording device. This simulates what someone would hear when I called them on the phone using the headphones. The noise cancelling in the Bose was excellent, and I only heard my voice. With the Sony, I could hear background noise. The Bose playback sounded like I was talking using a handset, and the Sony sounded like I was on speaker phone.

The Bose iPhone app does not let you calculate anything, and it does not have an equalizer. At first this annoyed me, and then I realized that the Bose was calculating the levels for each song to produce the best sound, so I didn't have to use an equalizer.

Also, when you're wearing the Sony, they are bulky and look geeky on. The Bose is more streamlined to the head. I personally find the Bose more comfortable on over glasses. The Sony seems to have some clamping to shut out the sound, and this is not comfortable over glasses. The Bose has very soft earcups and relies on the noise cancellation instead of physically clamping down on your ears.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
To begin with, this review is for the XM2 model. You may see two of these Sony Premium Noise Cancelling Headphones listed on Amazon and wonder what the difference is. The XM2 is the newest model for this year and is built with newer materials. Sony may have addressed the headband cracking issue of the previous model in this release. That is not certain, but complaint(s) seem to be very limited on that issue.

I have been wearing noise cancelling headphones for a very long time. Have tried many other brands including Bose and Audio-Technica. The Audio-Technica noise-cancelling headphones are quite good, but outdated technology wise. As for Bose -- some of you may know this already -- but they are generally not a good brand. Most of their innovation costs go into advertising how great their speakers and headphones are rather than into the product itself. The current QC35 headphones are pretty darn good, but I ended up returning them once I heard these Sony headphones.

By far, these are the most advanced and best sounding noise cancelling headphones for the price.

Setup is extremely easy. For my iPhone and iPad, I simply downloaded Sony's companion app which walked me through the setup process. To fully explain how painless it is to start using these headphones out of the box, let me say that I didn't even bother to open the instruction book and instead relied on the app. Even if I didn't use the app, you can pair these headphones with mostly any device by long-pressing the power button.

What I found rather neat is that the headphones have voice prompts which tell you when they are powered on or off, or when connected or disconnected.

The noise-cancelling is as good or better than the Bose or Audio-Technica where it eliminates approximately 95% of ambient noise. You will never obtain complete silence while just wearing the headphones, but once you start playing music, the ambient noise is completely eliminated, thus immersing you completely into the listening experience.

Two terrific features as far as gestures are concerned....

While using the headphones, you can temporarily turn off the noise canceling while cupping your hand over one of the headphones. This allows you to carry on a conversation with someone. Remove your hand and the noise-canceling resumes.

For iOS users, take your finger and press it against one of the headphone cups and Siri automatically activates so you can issue a command.

By the way, the Sony headphones easily paired with my Macbook Pro and iMac.

Music sounds spectacular. The highs are present without being overblown. The bass is present while not being too exaggerated. You don't get that "muddy" sound that cheaper headphones provide.

The headphones arrive in a nice oval case along with a USB charging and separate headphone connecting cord.

I realize that some may be concerned about the reports of headphone band cracking that was reported on the previous model. This was a concern of mine as well. Looking at this new model, the complaints of cracking seem to be very rare and if you look further into them via an Internet search, perhaps limited to a specific individual who is repeating the complaints on many sites. I don't want to fully make that accusation as I am not completely certain, but I was just not able to get a substantial amount of evidence to back up the claims of this model having headband issues. Sony has stated that this new model is made of newer materials and I am assuming it was done to address the problems of the prior model.

Let's just say that I have seen no cracking issues with my headphones.

THESE are the ultimate noise-cancelling headphones. Do not hesitate to pick these over other brands. You will be amazed by their performance.

Reviews:
I'm an old time audiophile, with over 20k lossless tracks — but I also travel a lot, so I need NC (noise canceling).
Using a carefully selected range of FLAC tracks, through a decent DAC, I tried all the top-ranked over-ear and in-year NC systems, of every brand I could get my hands on — but below $400, that's just my psychological limit for headphones.
My head and ears are normal size.

Pros:
These cans had the best balance between noise canceling and audio quality, hands down. There's just no comparison. Especially the active calibration is very useful in planes with "particular" engine sounds. I fly overseas (long flights) and use them for 7-8 hours without problems. I much prefer these to the Boses available in Executive/First class.

Cons:
The over-ear Boses (only comparable NC) feel smaller and lighter, and somewhat more comfortable. And of course, there are a bunch of great, more neutral, more audiophile cans out there.

Overall, strongly recommended.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
I had been eyeing the 1000x for a while now, having only ever used (on a daily basis) IEMs due to having thick hair and glasses. I finally decided to try it out, even though the in-store units I tried on were quite frankly terrible. I was very surprised, pleasantly so. The adaptive sound or sense engine works extremely well, exceeding my experience with the Bose QC35 and Bose QC20. For the QC35, I primarily could just not get a good seal and had sound leaking in as a result. I am very pleased with the sound quality, comfort, and noise cancellation ability of the WH-1000XM2. It doesn't blow anything out of the water if you have previously owned any Bose ANC unit, but it is an improvement in every way but one (including the touch-interface, which far outstrips the Bose units in ease of use).

The microphone quality is absolutely horrendous. The moment I attempted to
call someone, they muted me and told me I sounded like an incarnation of death and white noise. I thought it might just be an exaggeration, but after recording myself using the unit and the phone microphone, I can safely say that the WH-1000XM2's outbound voice quality is on par with an extremely cheap knockoff one could find at a dollar store. I am not sure if it is a defect or what, but I was definitely disappointed that one of the marketable features was not remotely serviceable in a completely silent room. Still, I didn't buy it for the microphone, and the rest of the features that this headphone comes with is well worth the price.

I would definitely recommend these over the Bose assuming it doesn't have the headband cracking issue that the MDR-1000x had. So far I haven't seen nearly as many reports of headband cracking on these.

One thing I wish they'd done something about was the ability to avoid pressing the touch controls when moving the headset on and off your head. That can get annoying if you're not careful. Now that I'm aware of the flaw it's pretty easy to avoid though.

Be aware that these headphones don't support simultaneous bluetooth devices. You'll have to manually disconnect from one before connecting with the other. That's not a big deal for me since I'll only want to use these with my phone, and god forbid I'd have to hold the bluetooth icon in the notification shade to bring up the bluetooth settings (NFC is overrated for the same reason).

The last thing to mention is the difference in Bluetooth codec between the Bose and Sony. Bose supports only AAC as a high-def codec, whereas Sony supports LDAC (of course) and AptX (thank god). Check the hi-def codecs your device supports before choosing a headset.

I guess I'd give these 4.5 stars if I could, because there are a couple of annoying issues with them. But having played them a lot over the last few days since receiving them, here are my thoughts in the hope that this may be helpful for someone like me, who is not an expert in anything. But I do enjoy music quite a lot.

Sound - 5 stars. This is what matters most, and this is what is the most subjective. That being said, I've owned quite a few headphones and earbuds over the years, and I am really enjoying these. To me, Bose products are somewhat overrated, and these sound better than the QuietComforts to my ears anyway. Of course the sound can't match high-end wired headphones connected to expensive output equipment, but considering that these are going without the wires, it's very hard for me to find fault with them. Warm overall sound, very good clarity, nice even bass without distortion. Excellent.

Build quality - 5 stars. They look and feel very solid. I got the gold ones, which are really more of a tan color, but really nice. Kept in the hard case that comes with them, I believe they will last a long time.

Comfort - 3 stars. After about an hour, they start to hurt my ears somewhat. That's been my experience to some extent with every pair I've owned, but hopefully I will get used to them over time. I find myself adjusting them quite a bit to get more comfortable. The ear cups are pretty tight, which obviously helps with:

Sound Isolation - 5 stars. My gym has a lot of noise, but these block out about 90% of it. I haven't been on a plane with them yet, but I think they will be just fine.

Features - 4.5 stars. I like being able to control everything by touching the sides of the headphones. But the right side volume, pausing, and skip ahead functions are very sensitive and take some getting used to. The two buttons on the left ear cup are small and hard to find by touching them, frequently causing me to hit the wrong one. The app (at least for the iPhone) has a lot of functionality, and I really like the customizable equalizer. That really makes a big difference for me. There are lots of other things (everything pretty much) that you can do from the app. Pretty cool. Other reviewers have mentioned problems with the app, but not me. There are lots of other features that are of questionable value to me personally (sound position, atmospheric pressure, virtual sound, etc.), but may be useful to others. Bluetooth/Pairing 4.5 stars. It pairs very easily to up to eight devices. The range is very good also. However, switching from one device to another is an unnecessary pain. You should be able to connect to two devices at a time. Minus a half star for that.

Battery - 5 stars. So far, so good. After 10 to 15 hours, battery level is still "medium".

For a long time I put off getting wireless headphones, fearing that I would have to sacrifice sound quality for convenience. Now you can have the best of both worlds.

Obviously for an entire conversation I'd just pause them and take them off, but just being able to hear something quickly and let go and go back to action to me is an awesome feature. #3 - the ambient noise settings/adjustments are great. The headphones can sense your activity (idle, walking, running, etc) and will adjust for ambient noise accordingly. You can also have the headphones focus on speech and drown out other ambient noise. I tested this feature out while the wife was watching TV. Its strange to not hear the sounds of cars and other usual noises but hear them talking well. Title: Wonderful sound, dreamlike comfort, with somewhat annoying bluetooth pairing.

Comments: One person found this helpful. Was this review helpful to you?
Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
I spend a lot of time traveling and wanted a good pair of ANC headphones. I’ve used the Bose QC 35’s in the past, and although those were quite good, positive reviews from friends led me to want to try the 1000XM2s.

For long-haul flights, these are a godsend. As I write this, I just out of a 23 hour travel experience, and I wore these headphones for the majority of my 3 flights. The battery lasted the entire time (and ANC was on), and I still show 20% battery (though, I imagine it’s a bit closer to 10%), and I was playing music or video for the vast majority of the trip.

At first I thought the “cup the right ear to pause/turn off ANC” would be a gimmick, but when trying to listen for announcements on the plane or in the airport, it was really useful.

I’m also a big fan of the control gestures on the right side. I have AirPods that I use for my general wireless usage (walking around/commuting to work), and the double-tap to pause/play action is identical. I also appreciate there being an easy way to skip/reverse tracks and to raise and lower volumes.

I typically don’t bother with third-party apps for EQ stuff, but out of boredom I was messing with it this trip and found that tuning the settings can give off great results. That said, I was very satisfied with the audio quality as-is.

The feature that allows the ANC to balance based on air pressure/altitude seemed to be really good, but that could just be placebo.

Speaking of ANC, it’s jusf fantastic. I know there are some complaints about it turning off when not in use (you have to plug something into the line-out to keep it active), but since I prefer my own traveling playlist over white noise, this hasn’t been an issue for me. Needless to say, the crying baby sitting two rows behind me in my 10-hour return flight from São Paulo to the United States didn’t bother me, which was nothing shirt of a miracle.

The included carrying case is great. Just don’t do what I did and leave it someplace in an airport in Brazil. Song does sell replacement parts, but they are expensive, relatively speaking ($60 for a case, $35 for a color-marched headphone cable). That’s my fault for leaving them, not Sony’s, but I thought I’d mention it.

Connectivity with my iPhone X and iPad Pro was great. It also works perfectly with my Apple Watch (if you want to use that to control playback). Pairing isn’t as instaneous as using W1-chip headphones (AirPods, Beats Solo 3 Wireless and the new Beats Studio 3), but it’s fast nonetheless. You do have to disconnect from one device before pairing to another (simply pairing won’t work, you need to disconnect the other device first), which is a mild annoyance. I would love more flawless device switching or support for multiple BT connections.

I’ve also used them with a mid-2017 MacBook Pro, a mid-2017 iMac 5K, and a late-2016 Surface Book with great success. I usually don’t use noise canceling headphones at work because too many people yell at me (wired Song MDR-7506s have been my default pick for years now), but these are excellent and especially convenient when trying to do work or even a quiet conference call from the airport lounge or the speaking room at a conference.

I can’t speak to long term durability yet, but so far these have more than met my expectations.

As far as comfort, I haven’t done a direct comparison with the Bose (the last time I used the Bose was close to a year ago), but these didn’t bother me, even after 10+ hours of continuous use.

From a pure sound quality point of of view, there are probably equally good or better options for less money on the market, but the battery life and excellent ANC makes these ideal for travel.

The built-in Google Assistant on the Bose is actually very helpful once you learn it's capabilities.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
My goal in buying over the ear headphones was mainly to control the noise level at work.

I work in a small office with several other folks, one of which in particular has a tendency to talk at length about random stuff at times when I really need to concentrate on work.

Loud sighs, sliding down in my chair behind my monitors, mumbled oaths and other unsubtle hints fell on deaf ears, and so to maintain an otherwise good relationship with this valued colleague I started looking for a solution, which lead me to a comparison of noise cancelling headphones.

As others have noted, these are fantastic at making the outside world go away.

On testing with my wife, I at first suspected she was having fun with me and just moving her lips - hand over the right headphone suspends the noise cancellation and I could hear her deliberately loud and goofy shrilling. Visualize Xena Warrior Princess battle cry.

At work, with or without low level music, my problem is solved and I can cheerfully donate a couple of minutes being a good listener here and there, knowing I can raise my shields at will.

Others more qualified to speak on sound quality may find fault with these, but to me they sound fine, particularly after adjusting various settings in the Sony Connect app for my phone.

At home, I've enjoyed using these with my Roku - I use the "private listening" feature on the Roku phone app to accomplish that.

I've worn them for hours at a time with no discomfort, and find the ear and headband padding adequate.

I like the gesture control and find it easy to remember and use. The "grab the right headphone to listen" thing is especially useful, and I make use of it frequently.

This is important for any noise cancelling headphone, and these Sony's have a reasonably good shell structure for blocking some sound passively. When the Noise Cancellation is On, I get to enjoy near total quiet where I normally sit, and I get plenty of protection when I go in and among the computers to do work up close to the whirring and buzzing cooling fans, which can be quite loud - up to 90 dB up close. I also used then while being driven around they do a great job at reducing regular car / freeway noise. They are robust but a tad fragile. I treat them like the sensitive electronic instruments that they are, and so should you. Protect them and they will serve you well. Sound quality is quite adequate for my needs - but this is not the true strength of this device. It is of course waaayyy better than any of the cheaper ones I have tried.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
I have been using the Bose QC35 headphones for about a year and really like them. However, I've seen such generally very positive reviews for the Sony MDR-1000X phones that, when this new model came out, I had to give them a shot. Since I was already very satisfied with the Bose, I knew that the Sonys had to be something special for me to keep both headphones.
When I received the Sonys and unpacked them, I was really excited to try them. The first thing I noticed was that the comfort level was several steps below the Bose. They felt heavier (which they are), tighter on my head, did not completely envelop my ears, and immediately felt too warm on my ears. Comfort is a very important factor to me, so I knew that the Sonys would have to be outstanding compared to the Bose on other factors.
So, let's go down the checklist:
1. Build Quality - As anyone who reads Amazon customer reviews of the MDR-1000X will see, cracking of the headband was a substantial issue, with associated poor customer service responses from Sony. I can find no mention that the issue was resolved on the new phones, although time will tell.
2. Noise Cancelling - Bose has been at the forefront of this for many years, but Sony has clearly caught up. However, for me, I needed the noise cancelling to be substantially better on the Sonys for me to keep them over the Bose. Although the Sonys have more noise cancelling options, I could not detect a marked improvement over the Bose.
3. Sound Quality - This is probably the most subjective factor under consideration. After a few hours of A/B comparison of the two headphones, it turned out that I prefer the Bose. To me, they have a cleaner sound with better instrument separation.
4. Features - Sony clearly outperforms Bose on this factor. From the many options on the Sony app, to the touch controls, to the Quick Attention Mode feature, it is obvious that Bose has a lot of catching up to do.

So, for me, the Sony advanced features are just not enough for me to use them over the Bose. Many thanks to Amazon for making the return process so easy.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
Product fits well, connects well, sounds great, and effectively blocks ambient noise. Audiophiles will prefer the sound of these over the Bose Q35's, and if you're a fan of deep bass (like me), again, you'll prefer these. The downloadable app for the headphones includes a customizable equalizer (not just a list of available presets like in Apple's music settings), and includes the option to increase bass specifically. This is important to me because by increasing the bass through the headphones themselves, rather than through the equalizer in my spotify app, I get the increased bass while bypassing the degradation in audio that characterizes bluetooth streaming. The LDAC system/High-Res Audio is great. The sound is noticeably better than the Q35's. If you purchase the Q35's you might notice that they sound great (bass included, it's very impressive) over a WIRED connection. But when transitioning to a bluetooth connection (e.g. from my Mac to my iPhone) the bass completely falls apart. It actually sounds like they're broken. This won't be an issue if you don't artificially increase the bass like I do (with the EQ in the spotify app), but if you like bass you will be disappointed. Not with the Sony pair though. The bass is great, the streaming quality is certainly superior, and the battery is phenomenal. Though for $350 I recommend getting the warranty. I've not experienced any "cracking" referenced in some other reviews (I've also had them for less than a month), but it was enough to scare me into getting the warranty. Which, considering the price of the investment, is really not a bad idea anyways.

Overall, highly recommend.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
It's probably too early to write a review, after all I've only had this headphone set for less than 24 hours as I write this. But so far this Sony WH-1000XM2--an impersonal, heartless name if there ever was one--has been an impressive kit, at least after I actually figured out how the controls worked on this unit. So far I like the sonic qualities well enough for a closed design. I also like the comfort as I spent time with these on my day off, listening to a multitude of streamed music off of Amazon's Unlimited service, as well as my own digital files stored on my tablet and my phone.

It's lightweight enough to be comfortable throughout longer listening sessions. Even with my large ears the earpads envelope them and confirm that the design is truly an over-ear headphone set. The battery life is as promised and is still going strong well into its first charge. Its noise cancellation skill seems to be credible enough; though I'll need a noisier environment than my washing machine and vacuum cleaner to be certain (it may be my day off but chores are chores). The swipe controls (on the right earpiece housing) aren't the most intuitive to me at first and do seem quite sensitive, but I'm getting used to how it works. Fit and finish, as well as the build quality and materials are still too soon to judge, but so far they seem decent enough for something that costs $300 less tax(bought on sale here on Amazon). Comparing them to the QuietComfort 35 that I also was considering, this one hasn't left me wanting...so far.

This 'review' is for now more of a placeholder than a comprehensive go-over of the Sony, but at least for a day this Bluetooth headphone set has my attention. 4+ stars, for now.

Day 2: I've discovered that the XM2's noise cancelling ability is truly impressive. I've also discovered that wearing this headset to bed has its downfalls; rolling over onto my right side (a natural tendency I have), the right earcup ended up putting a fair amount of pressure on my head just above my ear. About four hours in I awoke with the headset still in place (something of a surprise since with other headphones I have a habit of losing or removing them off of my head during sleep), I had a pronounced sore spot at that area above my right ear, no doubt caused by the XM2 pressing against my skull for a good amount of that time. Hours later I still feel the irritation from wearing the Sony set during that sleep period. Disappointing but truthfully not totally unexpected.

I also have begun to garner a growing dislike for the touch controls on this headphone set. It's awfully easy for me to unintentionally or inadvertently sweep across that touch control surface and "do something" that didn't need to be done with the settings. That's an annoyance that I'll need to adjust myself to. Frankly having dedicated hardware controls would've mitigated this, but probably in Sony's design staff's view would've compromised the unit's exterior aesthetics, which I must admit is nicely clean and without clutter. But sometimes sacrifices need to be made and in this case of overly sensitive touch controls, this is one of those instances that clean, sparse aesthetics should have taken a back seat to functional parameters.

Battery life is indeed tremendous, but it's a downer that the headset can't be used wirelessly when the battery is charging. In fact when the unit is charging it's not particularly usable even when the included mini patch chord is used. There's a lot of electrical noise leakage when the XM2 is being charged, and it's enough to my ears to quell any desire to use the headset when the micro USB power chord is plugged in. I've also discovered some irritating sonic qualities to the Sony's sound signature and imaging soundstage. Some music really comes off as being rather murky sounding, muddled in the lack of detail and presence, while other types or specific songs are considerably less noticeable as such. It doesn't have me tossing aside the XM2 and reaching for one of my open-back headphones just yet, but it's still disappointing nonetheless.

Still calling it 4+ stars, but inching slowly downward.

Day 14: Yeah, I do LIKE this set of headphones. The noise cancelling is still excellent and better than I imagined it would ever be. The sound quality is very good given its closed dynamics. The SQ will never approach my preferred preference for open-back headphones and (to me) their superior, more 'natural' spatial qualities, but for what it is this XM2's sound continues to please me. I've figured out where to adjust the headband to in able to relieve most of the pressure this design places on the top of my ear, so even from a comfort standpoint it's becoming a non-event. The touch controls remain the only annoyance, but I AM adapting. I just think that it shouldn't have to be such a pain, especially since fingering and swiping the side of one's head is not exactly a natural thing for humans (well, most of us anyway).

Definitely 4+ stars.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
These headphones are nothing short of incredible.

They block out all types of noises while also providing rich sounding audio. I've used these on the train and the amount of sound the noise canceling reduces is remarkable. One time on the train there was a woman playing the guitar literally across from me and I could just very faintly hear her with the noise canceling on and no music playing. Even my bus rides have been made so much more enjoyable just by wearing these headphones and being able to tune out the traffic just beyond my window.

In addition to the noise canceling, I like the fact that it can be turned off so you can let ambient sound in. Why you may ask? So when you're walking on a busy street or an intersection, you can still hear oncoming cars for safety purposes.

The fit is comfy and I like the foldable flat design. The touch controls are effective and I like being able to cup my hand over the right earcup if I need to speak to someone and don't want to take off my headphones. The battery life is excellent and they do well with all types of music from Jazz, to hip-hop, blues, vocals, you name it.

My only con is they can make my ears sweat after a prolonged period of time, so unfortunately I won't be wearing these during the summer. But I have earbuds for that, so I'm good. These ain't cheap but they're well worth the money.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
Great noise cancelling headphones with a few wrinkles. Consider saving yourself $100+ and buy the refurbished MDR-1000X/B which are last year's version and almost identical. I've taken both the 1000XM2 and the 1000X/B on a flight and compared the them by swapping back and forth repeatedly; both using only noice cancellation, and while listening to music and movies while also using noise cancellation. The noise cancelling between them is almost identical, but not quite. XM2 seem to have the slightest edge over the old X/B, but I suspect it is because of the earpieces, not the technology. If you look at the photo I've included with this review, you'll see the XM2 headphones have smaller openings for your ears. If you have a large head or ears, this is definitely noticeable when you're wearing them. I suspect this smaller opening contributes to the ever so slightly better noise cancellation on the XM2. And it is really slight. However, because of this tighter opening for the ears, the XM2 will make your ears hotter than the X/B if you're wearing them for hours at a time (e.g. on long flights).

As for the sound quality, both the XM2 and the X/B sound good, not great. If sound quality is top priority over noise cancelling, then go with the B&W PX or any number of other wired passive headphones. Here again, the XM2's tighter earpieces were a downside for me. They cause the soundstage move further toward the back of head, instead of out front where you really want it to be. The X/B put the soundstage right in between my ears, which still isn't awesome, but it's SLIGHTLY better than the XM2. Neither model can compete with a pair of good open cup headphones like the Sennheiser HD650. But then you get absolutely no noise isolation, so pick your priority.

Other oddities...the XM2 has textured faux leather on the ear cups, the X/B has smooth. I prefer the smooth. The touch controls on the XM2 seem more prone to error (skipping tracks when you just meant to change the volume) than the X/B.

TL;DR Apparently I'm turning in a grumpy old man who doesn't like change. The MDR1000X/B were great--why, Sony, did you change them for this? And get off my lawn!

EDIT: The above review was written before I tired the companion app. The app has a soundstage control ("Sound Position Control") that appears to be a crossfeed function. It fixes the "back of your head" soundstage problem I mentioned above. If you're reading this, Sony, please ditch the graphic EQ and adopt a parametric version where the user can just adjust the frequency response curve to their desired target. So much more useful than a graphic EQ.

Some other reviews mentioned the cracking issues on the MDR-1000X/B that I professed a fondness for. I haven't had any issues with mine, but others certainly have. Definitely take that into consideration. I also haven't had any issues with either headphones responding to pillows, seat cushions, hoods, or stocking caps. Capacitive controls shouldn't respond to pressure from everyday objects. That sounds like a defective headphone.

I purchased these headphones to replace a pair of Sennheiser RS160 for the ANR feature as I use them for watching TV simultaneously with my wife who listens through my surround sound system. I have hearing loss such that we can't find a volume that doesn't blast her out in order for me to hear. Even then, I struggle with speech clarity. I have then connected to two unused channels from my Denon 3300 AVR through an Avantree Priva III bluetooth adapter with APTX LL. I was concerned that the Sony WH1000 that although they have APTX they don't support low latency, but when I tried this combination dialog matching between picture and sound is very close and not a hindrance at all.

When I tested these haedphones at Best Buy I was standing next to a young mother with two toddlers that were anything but quiet at the time. Shut them out completely. At home, exterior noises are just about non-existant so this ANR is fantastic. The controls are easy and the headphones paired with the adapter right away on first try. They reconnect easily when I turn them on.

I have experienced a desire for a little more volume as many others reviews have pointed out but not enough to lower my rating. I am also concerned with the reports of cracking and so I am extra careful when handling the headphones The carrying case is not built very strong but I don't use them in that way.

For ANR, these headphones even the playing field with Bose if not exceeds the pricier headphones.

Reviews:
These headphones sound great, however in Bluetooth mode you can still tell sometimes that you are listening to Bluetooth headphones. There is still the typical Bluetooth sound signature. Don't get me wrong though, they sound excellent for Bluetooth headphones. Vocal bass is a bit weak, but instrumental bass is great. Mid-tones are good and have enough detail. Treble frequencies are very good. I find that to get the best sound, I have to put my iPhone equalizer on the treble boost setting, and as well, I have to put the Sony Connect app on it's treble boost setting also. Otherwise without these settings, the headphones sound muffled.

I find that I can have long listening sessions with these headphones without any temporary hearing loss or ear fatigue. I can not say this for all headphone I have used, so this is a positive.

The Sony mobile app has several features including a manual equalizer that works pretty well. The app has a surround feature to change the position of vocals. I don't know why anyone would want to use this feature, since it distorts already good sounding audio. The ambient sound auto-adjust feature can be turned on and off in the app. It is disabled by default.

The product is nicely manufactured and the headband does have enough pleather coated padding. I have not felt any discomfort wearing the headphones. I did not find the touchpad difficult to use; it works great. Noise cancelation is unusually good and I think this is the headphones strength. I feel that I made a good purchase. These do not sound as good as the Bowers and Wilkins P7wireless, but the ability to have very good active noise cancelation makes them a good buy. My only complaint about the headphones is that there is audible hissing during noise cancelation mode. Hopefully this will be corrected in the next model.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
Okay, I've only had these for a few days so these are my initial impressions. (I keep updating this review as I continue to use the headphones)

I've also bought the Sennheiser PXC 550 Wireless. The Sony ANC is *much* better than the PXC.

I found the PXC earmuffs got my ears very hot even in a room less than 70º F. I can't possibly imagine using them in the summer. The room I'm is 69º F. The headphones, and my ears, are 90º F. My ears are red.

ANC: I turned on a battery driven vacuum cleaner which is *extremely* loud. I normally wear commercial grade hearing protection when working with loud equipment. I tried on the Sony ANC and the noise dropped massively. The commercial grade hearing protection let in a lot more noise. But make no mistake, no ANC is going to magically remove all noise.

Switching between the Mac and iPhone is a massive pain. I don't think Sony could have made switching more difficult. Probably easier to have two sets of headphones because if you're using the headphones on the Mac and the iPhone rings, you will never, ever be able to switch before the calling party hangs up.

I find the Sony headset controls to be confusing. The PXC were easier to use.

Connecting to Siri on my iPhone X is completely hit-or-miss. The directions are all over the place. Double tap for 0.4 seconds (seriously?) and other directions state to press and hold. I would like to make a phone call from the Sony without having to get the iPhone out but I haven't found the magical press or tap or double tap to invoke Siri and say "Hey Siri, call Pizza". Update: Reading a different portion of the manual, I found that tapping the headphone will activate Siri.

I found this portion of the manual confusing:

"Make a request to Siri through the headset’s microphone.
When the iPhone is in standby or playing music, hold your finger to the touch sensor control panel to activate Siri.
Siri is activated and you will hear the start-up sound."

....then several lines down....

"Siri cannot be activated when you say “Hey Siri” through the headset’s microphone even when the iPhone’s [Allow “Hey Siri”] setting is on."

Can someone explain the apparent contradiction in instructions above or am I really dense?

Contrary to what the negative comments regarding the microphone, I found the Sony microphone to be clear (at least according to the person I was speaking to).

I'm not an audiophile but I found the sound quality to be very, very good in Bluetooth mode.

The Sony app annoys me. Why does Sony need to know my exact location at all times (even when running in the background) to work properly. How does it matter if I'm 5th or 6th avenue? The 'Privacy' EULA is over the top.

I have had the headphones on for about 30 minutes and my ears are very, very warm. There's not a chance I could use the Sony over the ears headphones in a warm (let alone hot) environment. These would be great for keeping your ears warm in the winter.

While I'm not thrilled with Bose, I'm going to a store to compare the Sony against the QC35 II for ANC and far more importantly, ear comfort.
If the headphones are very uncomfortable (hot and sweaty), I'm not going to use the headphone regardless of how great they sound.

Ugghh. My ears are burning up in the time I've written this review -- I've got to take them off.

If you're the type of person who tends to have cold ears, then these may be perfect you (if you can figure out the controls).

I'm probably going to keep these for a niche use: I spend a lot of time in waiting rooms where the TV is blaring putting a hole through my head. Yes, I could use high-quality noise ear plugs to virtually eliminate the noise but I want to listen to something. So for the 30-90 minutes I have to wait, I can tune out the mindless screeching from the TV and calmly listen to music from my phone.

Product: Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless...
Reviews:
So this was my third attempt at finding a pair of wireless over-ear headphones. My previous two were a cheaper set of Sonys and the Bowers & Wilkins PX. For various reasons, those did not work out, which led me to these. This will be the quickest I've ever returned a set of headphones. I had 4 main issues with these:

1. They did not fit on my head. Even on the tightest setting, they were too loose on my head. If I look up, they'd slide off backwards. If I look down, they'd slide off forwards. If I look left and right they slowly slide down my ears. Funny enough, I always thought I had a slightly larger than average head size, but apparently my head is not big enough to keep these headphones on them, even on the snuggest setting. This was massively disappointing as I did not see any other reviewers mention this.

2. The ear cup size is actually too small for my ears. These headphones are making me paranoid: am I a small headed, big eared freak? Seriously, the opening in each ear cup is too small to fit my ears, regardless of how much I shift them around. This made them ultimately feel like they're somewhere between on ear headphones and over ear headphones. Maybe they should brand them as Mostly Over Ear? It's uncomfortable not having your ears fit inside the cups.

3. Sound leakage. Good god these are awful in this category. It's embarrassing trying to ride the train and knowing that everyone around you can hear exactly what you're listening to. If you like to listen to music loudly, you may as well carry a boom box around because your neighbors within about 12 feet will hear everything you're listening to.

4. Swipe controls. This is the smallest complaint, and the only one that wouldn't be a deal breaker for me if it were the only issue I had with these. They're way too sensitive and I couldn't find a way to turn them off. The slightest adjustment I was trying to make to the ear cups, which happened often since they wouldn't stay on my head, would accidentally trigger the volume lowering or the song skipping or something. I'm sure with enough time I would perfect the art of tip-toe-ing around accidentally triggering the controls when adjusting the fit, but I will not own them long enough for that to happen.

So I guess I'll mention what these headphones do good: sound quality and noise cancellation. They are great at both of these things. So I guess if you're a big headed, small eared person who doesn't care that your neighbors can hear everything you're listening to, or maybe you just listen at home when no one else is around, or maybe you're just inconsiderate and don't care that everyone can hear your music, then feel free to buy these headphones. As for me, the quest to find a solid pair of wireless headphones continues.

Reviews:
Frequent Traveler who bought these primarily for flights.

Have Beats wired Studio noise canceling head phones, bought the Bose Q35 and compared to the Sony WH1000XM2. Also have Bose Wireless Sport headphones, Seinser wired ear buds, Bose wired sport buds, AKG buds I got with my S8 and I-Phone buds I got with my IPhone 6.

Sound Quality is subjective and very personal, my preference is the Sony's over all the headphones I currently have, non noise canceling and noise canceling.

Direct comparison to the Beats, Bose, the sound quality is preferred on the Sony as mentioned above, noise canceling very, very slight edge to the Sony, Bose and Sony are both well ahead of the Beats I own (4 year old model). Features, hands down the Sony absolutely blows away anything I've seen on the market. The App allows you to customize the noise canceling in useful, meaningful ways, has a customizable equalizer that allows you to personalize the sound in a meaningful way. The app also has surround sound settings that are gimmicky, didn't seem to do anything but take away from the sound quality. Being able to cup the right ear to turn off the head phones and hear someone is really great feature, being able to customize the noise canceling to filter out or allow voices and if you like automatically adjust based on your movement pretty cool.

On calls - I've read professional and personal reviews that all say phone calls are better on the Bose, I tested both, the Sony performed better for me, I was able to hear myself more clearly, others heard me more clearly on the Sony. The Sony's did pick up more ambient noise that was passed on to the caller on the other line.

Bluetooth connectivity is better than any Bluetooth headphones I have owned prior in regards to sound quality. Having no wires while traveling, getting on and off planes, wow, never realized what I was missing.

Comfort - Bose win out here - they are more comfortable, they cover the entire hear, create less heat around your ears and less pressure on your head, ears, face and jaw. Sony's aren't bad from a comfort standpoint but Bose is a level above any other over the ear headphones I've tried.

Overall I would say you have to try the various headphones on the market as so much of what you will or won't like about a particular pair is subjective. For me, the sound quality, the features and noise canceling won the day for me. Bose fell flat on a sound quality and feature standpoint, I actually preferred my Beats to the Bose on sound quality. The sacrifice is on the comfort front, no one beats Bose. If you are looking for noise canceling and that's a key feature, as other reviews have said, Sony and Bose are the best. Reviews:
Great sound, aesthetics, battery life, etc. but a couple issues in execution that prevent 4 or 5 stars.

USB Micro? Come on gang. Every time you release a product using legacy standards you have a chilling effect on adopting newer hotness. Used to not think the USB-C thing was a significant improvement, but its very nice not having to flip and fumble for that connection. Provide a cable for both USB-C to USB-C as well as a USB-A to USB-C; Since we're just using them for charging at standard USB rates, it doesn't have to be anything more than USB 2 or what-not. Literally no downside to USB-C for this kind of implementation. Or, better yet, QI maybe? Mmmmm... wireless charging... it's almost like someone willing to pay a couple hundred for premium wireless cans might be interested in wireless charging too... But for the love of all that is holy, don't use a proprietary connector (or inductive charging) like jaybird.

While we're talking about wireless and connectivity, what’s the deal with pushing the whole NFC connect? I love the forward-thinking interface, but the use-case is so small, and implementation so trouble ridden, it seems like it’s not adding any value. Yeah, conceptually it would be nice to use this instead of opening the Bluetooth connection options, but I'm usually switching between work-laptop, phone, and personal-laptop; while my phone has NFC, neither of the laptops have it, so that's kind of useless for 2/3s of my gear. Also, most people I know don't understand NFC, let alone bother enabling it on the devices that support it (my android stuff seems to default to NFC off; security risk maybe?). I suppose if they hardened the spec and everyone started using NFC for tap-to-pay then acceptance would pick up and more devices would have it, but considering Sony spun off their computers and their tablets don't even list NFC on their specs, it feels like a misguided feature that should have had the kids in marketing spend their UX thought elsewhere, like on the buttonless touch controls…

The capacitive stroking for volume and track changing is a neat trick and probably the right choice with regards to tech for physical control of the unit, but its unreliability and telegraphing make it a nuisance rather than an asset. Gotta reach up, place my hand around the can to reliably stroke the correct motion; it can take several strokes to get the motion right. Maybe put tactile guides for the finger to follow to increase reliability/consistency in motions, or, you know, maybe just a capacitive contact plate that I can feel and hold my finger on to send the same sort of signal. Less telegraphing of the finger and more consistency in sending the command (also looks less goofy than gently petting your headphones constantly).

Use similar contact plates for power-on and noise-cancel on/off settings. The current traditional buttons are too small to find easily and feel jankey when you push. Contact plates instead of a large stroke field seems like a win-win.

Finally! Connecting or powering-on the headphones causes the noise-cancelling (NC) to turn on. Considering that noise is usually not an issue and I value battery life over the NC, this is a genuine nuisance. I've already talked about the capacitive controls on the headphones increasing the complexity of interacting with the device, but continually reversing a setting I've enabled and turning on the NC every time I power-on or connect is NOT a value-add. I'm hoping there is a setting in the phone app that will allow me to disable NC on-at-connect or something (not going to hold my breath though).

Bottom line: My MDR-1RBTMK2's are more comfortable and have a more youthful aesthetic while these WH1000XM2's have a better sound stage, stay cooler on my head after hours of listening.

I think my MDR-1RBTMRK2's are still the cans to beat for wireless fidelity, battery-life and comfort but the WH1000XM2's are not bad by any means. Will keep one pair at home and one pair at work.

How they stack up against my other headphones:
- Grado 325 (best sound; literally painful to wear for long sessions; wired)
